Message.Title: Does Dell go to jail is they accept $13.62
Message.Msg: Seems there is no reason for them not to accept $14. It is a higher price for the small shareholders. The only way they would accept $13.62 is if the whole plan was to take Dell private in the 1st place. "With the board replaced under the Icahn-Southeastern plan, the newly installed directors would make a $14-a-share-cash tender offer for up to 72% of Dell stock. The buyback would allow unhappy investors to cash out, while increasing the ownership stakes of investors who stick around. " forbes. I want to stick around Dell is worth $50. There is no reason for management not to take the higher number, unless the plan was to screw the small investors to begin with.

Topic.Title: Class action suit

Message.Msg: They already have one suit filed against them that shareholders have been asked to participate in. If you feel paying below real book value for the compnay is a benefit to current share holders you must work for Dell. Michael Dell was supposed to lead and grow the company and not fall asleep at the wheel to later take the company private and profit from under paying for it.

Topic.Title: Class action suit

Message.Msg: Why do you keep referring to "book value" as though that is somehow relevant ? Book value is an accounting term, subject to much varied interpretation. Book value has nothing to do with what a company is worth to a potential buyer. In the DELL situation, there is no better revelation of "value' than the recent months of auction, when any and all interested buyers were permitted to access DELL's accounting books and present an offer to buy the company. That is the best "value test' of all, the free market. No outsider was interested enough to even match Mike Dell's $13.65 offer. much less beat it. Hope this helps.

Topic.Title: voted my 5k shares AGAINST dell and silverlake

Message.Msg: Welllll...I bought in today after hearing about this on CNBC...read up real quick on the particulars...but, apparently not enough. After reading the statement from the fund supporting Icahn, I was hoping he would get the vote: the 14 pps sounded like easy money....BUT, after a lot more DD, I realize the Dell option is by far the best for the company, AND shareholders. Do DD and see....just IMO....I do note that the year target by analysts is 13.94...that would be nice if MD would raise his offer to that amount.....but I can see , now, why he doesn't/can't. Personally, I wish Michael Dell good luck.
